Award.AwardTitle: Modular Synthesis of N-Glycans and Homogeneous Glycoproteins
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project led by Professor Chi-Huey Wong at The Scripps Research Institute. His group focuses on the development of a new combination of chemical and enzymatic methods for the synthesis of complex oligosaccharides to be attached to proteins to form homogeneous glycoproteins such as antibodies. Most of the proteins in humans and other higher organisms have various sugars attached to form a heterogeneous population of glycoproteins. As a result, it has been difficult to understand the roles sugars play in glycoproteins. This project establishes effective methods for the synthesis of complex oligosaccharides and their use in the assembly of homogeneous glycoproteins containing well defined oligosaccharide structures. Access to these homogeneous glycoproteins allows us to understand how the oligosaccharide affects the functions of proteins and how to make better glycoproteins as medicines or as reagents. This multidisciplinary project presents a rich environment for the training of young scientists.

Understanding the effect of glycosylation on protein folding, structure and function is vitally important in biology and medicine and requires access to a large number of complex N- glycans. These oligosaccharides could be assembled using the modular method described in the project, which breaks down the task of N-glycans synthesis into the chemoenzymatic preparation of branched modules and the chemical synthesis of the core unit. The synthesis of branched modules (Specific Aim 1) begins with seven synthetic intermediates, which can be diversified using enzymatic transformations to generate a number of modules. Chemical synthesis of the core oligosaccharide is being optimized to provide N-glycans tailored to a specific application, therefore increasing the utility of this method (Specific Aim 2). Using the synthetic N-glycan samples, new glycoforms of a representative monoclonal antibody are being prepared for the study of their activities (Specific Aim 3). All modules, enzymes, and reagents developed in this study are made available to the community to facilitate our understanding of protein glycosylation and to advance the research in glycoscience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Protein glycosylation is acknowledged as one of the most important post-translational modification, capable of significantly affecting protein folding, conformation, stability and involved in various inter- and intracellular recognition events. The structural microheterogeniety arises from post translation glycosylation constitute a major challenge in studying the role of glycosylation in biological processes and functions. Therefore, development of methods for the preparation of complex carbohydrates and glycoproteins in pure form and sufficient quantities, and for the analysis of glycan sequences is of particular interest to the glycoscience community. To address the need, our group has been involved in solving the problem of complexity associated oligosaccharide synthesis by developing effective chemical and enzymatic methods for making N-glycans and homogeneous glycoproteins. The structural diversity was generated by stereo-and region-selective glycosylation of ManGlcNAc2 core with a set of oligosaccharyl Man-F modules prepared chemoenzymatically. The N-glycan structures originated from this strategy are useful for the development of a glycan microarray for studying the glycan binding specificity of HIV-1 broadly neutralizing antibodies and understanding the receptor-binding specificity of Influenza A virus HA proteins, and for developing glycan sequencing methodology and antibody Fc-glyco remodeling.

While studying the effect of Fc-glycosylation on antibody effector functions, we found that a bi-antennary complex type N-glycan terminated with 3Fax-Neu5Ac exhibited excellent stability against sialidases. The binding to Fc-γ receptors was also improved and ultimately the ADCC activity. Based on our preliminary results, it is highly expected that the antibody with this particular glycoform would exhibit better in-vivo stability. To make the F-sialylated N-glycan for in-vitro glycoremodeling studies, we prepared the glycan by the one pot strategy pioneered by our group. The one pot strategy is programmable and was further implemented for the synthesis of other heparin related structures with diverse sulfation pattern.

Intellectual Merit:

The modular chemo-enzymatic approach that we have developed for the assembly of structurally diverse glycans is very efficient and scalable and requires minimum number of building blocks. The structural diversity was generated by using various glycosyl transferases rather than full chemical synthesis. The core structure can be selected based on application; for example, for the glycan array application, the full structure ManGlcNAc2 is required, while for in-vitro glycoprotein remodeling only ManGlcNAc is needed. All the structures equipped with pentyl amine linker can be easily used for printing on array surface, conjugation to carrier protein, dendrimer, or nanoparticles for further studies.

Broader Impacts:

The ultimate goal of your work was to develop efficient synthetic methods to enable the study of protein N-glycosylation and its effect on protein folding, structure, and functions. In nature, glycoproteins are existing as complex mixture of glycoforms, which are difficult to obtained in pure homogeneous forms by using traditional methods to understand the role of glycosylation. The methodologies we developed here have offered efficient access to a large number of complex glycans and glycoproteins. Moreover, the fluoride modification in terminal sialic acid of antibody Fc-glycans improved the stability against glycosidase in vivo without compromising the effector functions. This research will advance our knowledge in biological glycosylation and enable the design of new and improved glycoproteins.


Last Modified: 07/17/2020
Modified by: Chi-Huey Wong
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Protein glycosylation is acknowledged as one of the most important post-translational modification, capable of significantly affecting protein folding, conformation, stability and involved in various inter- and intracellular recognition events. The structural microheterogeniety arises from post translation glycosylation constitute a major challenge in studying the role of glycosylation in biological processes and functions. Therefore, development of methods for the preparation of complex carbohydrates and glycoproteins in pure form and sufficient quantities, and for the analysis of glycan sequences is of particular interest to the glycoscience community. To address the need, our group has been involved in solving the problem of complexity associated oligosaccharide synthesis by developing effective chemical and enzymatic methods for making N-glycans and homogeneous glycoproteins. The structural diversity was generated by stereo-and region-selective glycosylation of ManGlcNAc2 core with a set of oligosaccharyl Man-F modules prepared chemoenzymatically. The one pot strategy is programmable and was further implemented for the synthesis of other heparin related structures with diverse sulfation pattern. The structural diversity was generated by using various glycosyl transferases rather than full chemical synthesis. The core structure can be selected based on application; for example, for the glycan array application, the full structure ManGlcNAc2 is required, while for in-vitro glycoprotein remodeling only ManGlcNAc is needed. In nature, glycoproteins are existing as complex mixture of glycoforms, which are difficult to obtained in pure homogeneous forms by using traditional methods to understand the role of glycosylation. The methodologies we developed here have offered efficient access to a large number of complex glycans and glycoproteins. Moreover, the fluoride modification in terminal sialic acid of antibody Fc-glycans improved the stability against glycosidase in vivo without compromising the effector functions. This research will advance our knowledge in biological glycosylation and enable the design of new and improved glycoproteins. Last Modified: 07/17/2020 Submitted by: Chi-Huey Wong
